comments.text:
I've always been a fan of Power Grid.  It has the pseudo-economy of the 
typical anti-randomness Euro boardgame, but the physical map makes it less 
obtuse than something like Puerto Rico where nearly everything is 
conceptual, while at the same time avoiding the complicated visualization 
that something like Ticket to Ride has.

But my favorite boardgame of all is one that straddles the point-tallying 
of Euro games and the randomization factor of American games called 
"Survive" aka "Escape from Atlantis" from the 80s, where the goal is to 
help your tribe escape a sinking island before your opponents, removing a 
map tile each turn.  Since the map tiles *are* the action cards, the very 
act of picking a card is a strategic decision.  You never quite play the 
same map twice.

top_comment.text:
You answers for the amendment part of your video were all REALLY BAD IDEAS.
Change 1. Adding taxes for campaign elections would sap money from 
EVERYONE, and even at that, it wouldn't go to a worthy cause.
Change 2. The Senate was made along with the House of Representatives, 
which is a proportional body, because when the Constitution was made the 
small states and large states argued about power. The senate gives power to 
the states while the House of Reps, which is proportional, gives power to 
the people of the states, giving states with more people more power.
Change 3. Interstate commerce was made so that the states, when first 
created during the Constitutional Convention, wouldn't overtax each other 
and to prevent them to act more like independant countries. Back then, 
having UNITED states (the states acting as one body) rather than united 
STATES (Each state very different with one common goal, making it 
comparable to the European Union of today) was vital to beating the UK in 
the war.
Sorry for the long post, but hope you agree with me!﻿

comments.text:
+dave19941000 "it's still undemocratic no matter which way you look as it,

Again, you must have forgotten about the House of Representative being the

voted into office, but appointed. You've mixed apples and oranges for so 
long you think them both to be apples. When you place "voter support" 
behind the state's represenative, you are all mixed up.

Now, if I try to explain basic US civics any more simply, I'd have to go

an adult (or maybe a teen over 16, if it must come to that).

As for the numbers on slavery... Hazah and hurray. The Founders tricked the

out. I'm proud of that. But the result has nothing to do with the purpose,

comments.author: Benjamin Abruzzo

comments.text:
Uh, no, it's still undemocratic no matter which way you look as it, as you 
can have a majority in the senate with only 13.8% voter support. There is 
quite literally no other democratic system that allows for 86.2% of the 
vote to be against your party and still not only give you power, but 
majority.

As for the slavery issue, given that at no point in the history of the 
Union has the south come close to numbering the population of the north, 
the existence of the senate as a 2 seats per state system would have worked 
in favor of the slave states, not against them, so don't try to lie about 
it.

Yes, there should be checks and balances so that the large states don't 
push the small ones around, but no, the small minority should not have de 
facto control over everything that gets passed. At this point one has to 
wonder why California, Texas and New York aren't giving serious 
consideration to leaving the union given the balance
 of voting power.
comments.author: dave19941000

comments.text:
+dave19941000 "so you don't have to openly state you don't want the US to 
be an equal republican democracy where all are represented fairly."

Here's a direct statement: I don't want a direct democracy because I want a 
fair representative system in the republic. By curring out the 
representation of the smallest voices, diminishing them from an equal 2 out 
of 100 to a tiny fraction, you reduce the fairness.
comments.author: Benjamin Abruzzo

comments.text:
+dave19941000 "We advocating one person = one vote. You are advocating 76 
Californian's vote = 1 Wyoming vote. It's as simple as that"

To borrow a phrase "Here's the problem with that logic"... I think you 
missed the part where that "76 Californian's vote = 1 Wyoming vote" is 
happening in the House of Representatives.

Remember, I said the Senate represents the states, not the people. The 
point of the Senate is so that New York or California or (in the days of 
slaves) Virginia or The Carolinia couldn't impose their ways on New 
Hampshire, Vermont, RI and so on. The 1 state, 2 vote system is to veto the 
slave states from making slavery permenant and today it is a way to keep 
from making anti Wyoming laws because New York wants them.

"I also like how you keep trying to make it look like we want to make the 
votes proportional to anything other then population so you don't have to 
openly state you don't want the US to be an equal republican democracy 
where all are represented fairly."

But you are represented fairly. In your state, you have fair elections (I 
hope). In the House, it is based on population. But you seem to forget (or 
dismiss) my point that the US federal government has certain powers and the 
rest are given to the states (where you do have representative elections, I 
hope). But when the states powers are being trampled upon by other states 
or the federal government, then you are supposed to have the Senate to hold 
them back.

You seem to think that the United States of America is only people. it 
isn't. It is, in facr people, states, cities, communities, counties and so 
on... all of which have their own contribution. And you didn't like when I 
mentioned that degrading the Senate's powers to protect the states (and by 
doing so protect the cities, counties, communities and people with in those 
states) basically takes a voice away from the republic.
comments.author: Benjamin Abruzzo

comments.text:
"Because Senators represent states, it is more fair to have the state 
legislators and govenors appoint them. Thus legislators are subject to 
their local districts and voters, thus making them more representative of 
their state and responsible more directly to their voters."

Here's the problem with that logic, it still means that the states with the 
least people have more power in making federal laws. We advocating one 
person = one vote. You are advocating 76 Californian's vote = 1 Wyoming 
vote. It's as simple as that.

I also like how you keep trying to make it look like we want to make the 
votes proportional to anything other then population so you don't have to 
openly state you don't want the US to be an equal republican democracy 
where all are represented fairly.
comments.author: dave19941000

comments.text:
+Nicholas Scott Let's simplify it for you, then. House members represent 
the people, the Senate represents the states. You take 50 states and divide 
them equally by number, you have 50. You can either give each state a fair 
representation by being 2/100th, the same as all other states (one state, 
two votes, just like one person one vote) or you recognize that each state 
is a land mass and give it based on proportion on size (which would be the 
same as giving a person the amount of votes based on how much money they 
have).

Because Senators represent states, it is more fair to have the state 
legislators and govenors appoint them. Thus legislators are subject to 
their local districts and voters, thus making them more representative of 
their state and responsible more directly to their voters.
comments.author: Benjamin Abruzzo

comments.text:

rest of what I said.

Your statement applies equally to "I'm glad you're a fan of mob rule". But,

argument, rather than logic.

The tenth amendment has absolutely nothing to do with the conversation 
topic, "Is the Senate a fair system of representation?" And your argument 
is, literally, 'This is what the system is and therefore it is fair and

comments.author: Nicholas Scott

comments.text:
+Nicholas Scott "get that you're a fan of the elite rule system"

All represenatives are beholden to the people every 2 years. The Senate is 
meant to represent the state. To ignore that representation or to move it 
to one side or another is like a discussion of an abortion. You have the 
mother, the father, the doctor, but nobody representing the child. It might 
be insignificant to you that the states have the 10th Amendment and the 
Federal government have enummerated powers, but ignoring that is what has 
gotten this country as messed up as it is.

And yes, "majority vote" without another checking to see if it is 
Constitutional, if it is for the good of their represented party is mob 
rule. It tends to "the loudest" get served to and the "smallest" get served 
up.
comments.author: Benjamin Abruzzo

comments.text:
+dave19941000 Again, it sounds like you want the people represented 
proprotionately, not the state. To represent the states proportionately, 
you must look at the state itself. Here you have two options, the state as 
a whole or the state as land mass.

So a state being represented proportionately would either be 1 out of 50 or 
what we have now 2 out of 100 (or what we had at the 
Declaration/Constitutional conventions 3 per state. Or you do it by land 
mass, giving Alaska the most representation as it is the largest. Of course 
you get inti "land mass owned by the state vs owned by the federal 
government, in which case Utah becomes the smallest state, as it is 95% 
owned by federal parks.

Remember, also, that the population is represented in the choosing of the 
Senators under the original meathod: the legislators are voted in by the 
local people of the state and are accountable to the people. The Governor 
is voted in by a state-wide election. And it was they who picked the 
Senator. Pick the wrong Senator and it was just like voting on the wrong 
road or school bill.

So, the state is not above the voting of the people, but ttrapped inside 
and accountable to them. It gives more people a better link to the Senator 
in DC, while the Senator still looks to the votes of the legislatore and 
the good of the state rather than running for popular vote.
comments.author: Benjamin Abruzzo

comments.text:
I get that you're a fan of the elite rule system, but to me it seems a 
little crazy that the more powerful of the two bodies is the one that most 
disproportionally represents the population.

Especially when this was written for a time when the US thought of itself 
as a collection of small countries more than a country unto itself. Giving 
all states an equal say in the most powerful legislative body in the land 
makes sense in that historical context. Giving all the people an equal say 
in the most powerful legislative body makes sense in the modern context.

If that equates to 'mob rule', I guess you can just pass me the pitch fork 
and torch.
comments.author: Nicholas Scott

comments.text:
The problem is that the system as it stands is a carry over from a 
different era. The idea that all states should have a voice is agreeable, 
the reality that 21 states should hold 42% of the Senate while having a 
lower combined population of lower then California, well if there was ever 
a more appropriate time to use the phrase "the US was made to be a smaller 
country", I can't think of it.

The idea that any body doing the function of the Senate should have all 
states represented equally also has one very large flaw, that all states 
should be represented equally. This is impossible to do functionally, and 
the means by which it is currently done is an insult to the idea of 
republican democracy having all considered just as important and equal 
within.

As for your ideal of states being above the people for the law making 
proses, I find that to be the antithesis of the democratic proses, and the 
advocacy of the disenfranchisement of the 65% of Americans who are 
underrepresented in this system. Veto power is one thing, minority majority 
by design is another.
comments.author: dave19941000

comments.text:
+dave19941000 I get that you prefer more a mob rule structure that bypasses 
the state in its entirety. But we already have a proportional 
representative part of government called the House of Representatives. 
However, the states, which do have recognized rights under the US 
Constitution, have been seeing their representation vanish. The fact that 
Rhode Island and Wyoming get the same representation as New York or 
California is important. And, if it were based on appointment of the state 
legislator, it would be more accountable to the delegates/state senate, 
which are accountable to their communities, making it a much more fair 
system than currently exists.

The people get representation in the house, the states get representation 
in the Senate and the law gets arbitrated in the Supreme Court. The 
President carries out the laws, not changes them to his whim. At least, 
that is how it is meant to work.

So, it doesn't over represent any state to have equal voice in the 
government.  I find your idea of which state have the right size over 
idealistic and it ignores reality, that each state gets equal say, 
proportionate to the number of states that exist.
comments.author: Benjamin Abruzzo

comments.text:
The proportionate part is based on population, since the current Senate 
structure of 2 seats per state basically means that the less populous 
states have a massive overrepresentation. For a system that is built to 
pass or edit or defeat laws that effect everyone, it's an imbalance that 
gives far to much power to the small states and is in a way saying that 
some people in the country are more important just for where they live.

Say what you will about any system, the idea that each state should have 
equal representation is simply a self serving one for (at times 
cartoonish) overrepresentation by 32 states while giving them unjustifiably 
influence on the laws over the 12 states that are (again, at times 
cartoonishly) underrepresented, with only 6 states in the Union having 
justifiably sized representation.
comments.author: dave19941000

comments.text:
+tresortossaable
 That's a good question, and sorta ties in with CGP Grey's videos about the 
history of the UK. Even though England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern 
Ireland forms one official nation, each of those different parts of the UK 
consider themselves to be a nationality.

In the US, "Scottish" is considered a "nationality." "English" is a 
nationality. Irish is a nationality. Welsh is a nationality. French, 
German, and Italian are all nationalities. See how that works? Italy has 
one nationality. France has one nationality. Germany has one nationality. 
The UK has four.

The reason why I used the US, is because the US, like the rest of the New 
World, is unique. The only native "nationality" in the New World are Native 
Americans. The rest of us are descendants from Europe, Asia, and Africa. So 
it is rather customary, when discussing bloodlines, to refer to an Old 
World nationality. For instance: I am German, Italian, Scottish, and 
French. A typical American mutt I am.

In the UK, it is even stronger than that. Each section of the UK so 
strongly identifies themselves by their heritage, and they actually call it 
their "national heritage.

Here in the USA, we are "Americans," and in Canada, they are Canadians. 
Mexico has Mexicans. And etc. There is no "United Kingdomian." They are 
either Scottish, English, Welsh, or Irish. Each nationality is so proud and 
so strongly self-identified, that the governing body of the UK soccer 
federation gives each section of the UK its own national team. Hence: Why 
you see England in the World Cup. You could just as easily see Scotland 
there. Or Wales. Or Northern Ireland.

captions.text: # Q&A with Grey `#2 (One Million Subscribers)
Hi.

So I think this is the part where I'm supposed
to have a dramatic opening, perhaps the 2001

theme song playing in the background as the
number 1,000,000 fades into view, but obviously
that's not happening.

Don't get me wrong, I'm lucky that so many
people want to watch my videos. It's just

that one million is a number too large to
be comprehended with a monkey-derived brain.

To try and have it feel more real I've takes
some YouTube data and made a spreadsheet!
(I make lots of spreadsheets)

You can select your country and enter the
population of the city where you live, and

it will spit out the statistically approximate
number of other people in that city who are
subscribed to this channel.

Doing that for London shows there are about
9,000 people in the city who are subscribers.

Now 9,000 is obviously smaller that one-*million*
but it's a number with constraints and is

small enough to possibly be understood while
still large enough to be very intimidating.

So, if you're interested, you can click here
to play around with the spreadsheet. Now,
as promised: on to the Q&A.

## What do you like most about being a YouTuber?
--Conzo_K

The best thing about this strange new world
is the people I've met -- which is quite the

statement for a social recluse to make. All
these guys are amazing to talk with and I

feel very lucky that I get the occasional
chance to do so.

## What's the biggest change of opinion you've
had? --Steam23

That's a little too personal to share with
say, one-*million* people, but I do want to

talk about the importance of being able to
change your mind in general.

The trick is to keep your identity separate
from your opinions -- they are objects in

a box you carry with you and should be easily
replaceable if it turns out they're no good.

If you think that the opinions in the box
are *who you are* then you'll cling to them
despite any evidence to the contrary.

Bottom line: If you want to always be right,
you need to always be prepared to change your
mind.

## Were you trying to create a unique aesthetic
by using stick-figures? --Waggles_ 20
No it's just that I can't draw.

## After moving to London how long did it
take until you stopped saying 'Math' and started
saying 'Maths'? --brockheinz
I haven't -- I'm sticking with 'math'.

Americans living in the UK often end up with
an unfortunate accent I call 'psuedo-british'.

I try very hard to avoid this, but when you've
spend the majority of your talking time with

British people over a decade it's impossible
to completely fight the creeping pseudo-british

accent no matter how abhorrent you think it
makes you sound.

## Did your students know about your YouTube
channel? --qiyitam

I would never talk about it, but I know some
of them knew. However it's impossible to express

how little they cared. My classes were like
not hour-long CGP Grey videos.

## Would you like to see the interrobang more
widely adopted? --aaronboardley
Who wouldn't‽

## Why don't you have an upload schedule?
--ManavT

Right: the big question. Usually phrased in
the YouTube comment section as 'y u no make
moar vids'?

So on average over the past couple of years
I've posted a 'Grey Explains' video about

every five weeks, which means if I could switch
to a weekly schedule my income would *quin*tupple.
Trust me, I would if I could.

I've talked before about how long it takes
to make these videos, but one of the other

problem I haven't mentioned is the failure
rate of projects.

For every video you see there's at least two
or three that didn't make it.

Most of the time that's just a lost afternoon
of working on an idea before realizing it's

a dud, but sometimes it's weeks before a fatal
flaw reveals itself -- sometimes I'll discover

too late a central fact of the video isn't
correct or, sometimes the whole script is
just unfixably *boring*.

Either way the decision to kill a video that
isn't working is depressing and frustrating
because of the sunk cost of all those hours.

The videos you see are (mostly) pretty good
precisely because I try my best to kill the

ones that weren't -- that's why there isn't
a schedule, and there never can be.
## What's the biggest video you killed? --tyroncs

The most time I lost was on an important video
to convince the world why *Settlers of Catan*
is the greatest board game ever made.

I had a couple thousand words as a starting
point, harassed people for footage of a now-famous

game that took place at YouTube EDU, got a
bunch of random videos from my ever-helpful

twitter followers had a and an outline for
a 'How to Play Settlers of Catan' tutorial
video for my second channel.

But the script kept growing and growing and
began to look more like a documentary film

on board game design than a YouTube video
-- which might, depending on who you are sound

really interesting, but it had the boring
problem I mentioned before.

My last ditch effort to save a project like
this is to get rid of everything, work on

something else for a few days, then write
a brand new script by hand -- which I did.

But that script still wasn't good and weeks
after starting the project I shelved it. But

I'm talking about it now because it's an idea
that I still just can't let go and might come
back to some day.

## Why don't you hire people to help you?
--WhoAteEarth

That's a big topic that deserves more time,
but for now let me just say the kind of work

produced by individuals is very different
than kind work of produced by groups. One

isn't intrinsically better than the other,
but I think the kinds of videos I've made

have all benefited from being a one-man project
from start to finish.
## Your opinion on koalas. --blanket_warrior

They sleep 20 hours a day -- never going to
be a koala-based civilization with that kind
of work ethic.

## If you could transfer your brain into a
robotic body, would you? --xyon21
Obviously yes.

## You can add three amendments to the US
constitution. What do they do? --raloon

Oh, so many tempting changes to make. Off
the top of my head I'd say:

1. Abolish private funding of all elections
and instead make them run from a limited pool
of tax money.

2. Abolish the Senate and replace it with
some kind of proportional body.

3. Overturn the Interstate-commerce clause
-- which basically gives the federal government
too much power over the affairs of the States.

Of course, if it was actually my responsibility,
I'd consult with some experts rather than
just idly mull it over for a couple of days.

Running a country of 300 million is more complicated
than it looks.

## What advice you would give for a successful
life? --pringlesaddict99

Build a self-evaluation loop in your life.
If you don't periodically review your actions,

their effects and your decision-making process
there hope for improvement other than random
chance.

I do very small weekly reviews, and bigger
quarterly and yearly reviews of how my life

is going and how I might want it to be different
in both the biggest and smallest ways.

That's the best, high level advice I have.
For more tactical advice I recommend two books:

one that changed my life *Getting Things Done*
by David Allen and another that might change

yours: *So Good They Can't Ignore You* by
Cal Newport. You can click those books to
read my reviews of them.

## Have you made a video you don't like how
it came out? --Gourounaki

With the exceptions of the 2012 and Holland
videos, I'm unhappy with *all of them*. I

don't watch my own videos after upload if
I can possibly avoid it: they're graveyards
of the could-have been.

## Favorite non-educational YouTube channels?
--DB101

1st: Glove and Boots, who I'm suprised haven't
yet gotten ALL THE SUBSCRIBERS. 2nd: I'm a

also huge fan of Yahtzee, the Roger Ebert
of video games.

## What was your first memory of the internet?
Mine is playing flash games. --vicorator

Mine is B.B.S.s. Now get off my lawn and go
watch this documentary you whippersnapper.
## Who are your heros? --reed17
Mostly Dark Seer and Necrolyte.

## What do you find hardest when making a
video? --willdood

Writing the script is the hardest and unfortunately
it's the bottleneck for the whole process.

The most *uncomfortable* part is editing the
audio. Just like everyone else there is a

voice in my head that I like and a voice on
the tape that I don't.

## Have any of your answers from your previous
Q&A changed? --MessiahPenguin
You're probably referring to these, and no.

## How long would you survive a zombie apocalypse?
--One_Wheel_Drive

I wouldn't. If a Walking-Dead-style zombie
apocalypse arrises the correct course of action
is suicide.

## What do you listen to while making videos?
--syphen94

My most reliable writing music is Girl Talk's
'All Day' which I would link to on YouTube

but it's copyright-infringement-tasktic. But
you can get it from his website and if you
like remixes you should give it a listen.

However, I often get some random terrible
song in my head while writing and end up buying

it and putting on repeat -- for hours. For
this script my iTunes reveals I listened to

a single song 127 times. That might be torture
in some jurisdictions but the repetitiveness
really zones me into writing.

Animating, however, is incredibly tedious
so I listen to a ton of podcasts and audiobooks
to keep my sanity.

## What's the most interesting 'could-have-been'
of history? --SCE-2-AUX

Historical-could-have-beens mostly strike
me as a missing-the-point thought exerciese.

The real driver of history is neither great
men nor the actions of the masses but the

ceaseless march of science and technology,
which is mostly indifferent to the imaginary
lines drawn by packs of monkeys.

Knowing my perspective you'll see why if I
*had* to pick one it would this primitive
greek steam engine invented 2,000 years ago.

There are reasons why it wasn't developed
further but if some rich Greek had gotten

obsessed with the technology perhaps we would
have had an industrial revolution two millennia

earlier and we'd now be a trans-galactic-post-singularity
civilization. With robot bodies.

## What is the most British thing you have
encountered that you can't get your head around?
--vikihogg

The idea that the best way to cool down on
a summer day while confined to a non-air-conditioned

office is to drink hot tea. Madness, absolute
madness.

## Should we create a universal language?
--vsa11
We already have, it's just not very universal.

## What question do you want me to ask the
most? --Gregorian_Hawke
Hmmm…

## I love your videos and have even watched
this somewhat tedious one until the very end.
How can I help support you? --Gregorian_Hawke
I'm glad you asked Gregorian_Hawke.

The best way is though a subscription at subbable
where you can get signed posters and other

stuff, and there’s also t-shirts and addiction
mugs (and flamethrowers) over at DFTBA.

Well Internet, it's been fun. And I'm sorry
if you're question didn't make it into this

video -- there were loads I had to cut -- but
now that we're in this realm of numbers so

big they don't make sense perhaps I'll turn
Q&A's into an occasional random thing rather

than a waiting for an arbitrary base ten roll
over thing.

Thank you again to everyone for your continued
support and thank you for subscribing and

for watching -- these last two years have
been quite a ride.
